details: Nothing noteworthy to report except that his title had the added bit "The Younger".
Was given the title Viscount Sidmouth (the 1st) in 1805 after retiring from Parliament.
Died in office.
Became the 1st Baron Ellenborough in 1802 so he might have been referred to as Baron or Ellenborough in Parliament.
3rd Marquess of Lansdowne in 1809 after his father died, and he lost his seat and office but he remained a prominent member of the Whig party until he passed in 1863.
Nothing noteworthy to report.
Was granted the title/peerage 1st Baron Bexley of Bexley in Kent county in March 1823 after his time in Parliament.

Was granted the title Viscount Goderich in january 1827, was later granted the peerage 1st Earl of Ripon to recieve Garter from the King, since a viscountcy was not sufficient for the role. (Wikipedia:Pike, E Royston (1968). Britain's Prime Ministers. London: Odhams pg. 177)
Nothing noteworthy to report.
Was granted peerage (Baron Tenterden) in April 1827 of Hendon in Middlesex county, he may have been referred as such in the speeches.
Nothing noteworthy to report.
Nothing noteworthy to report.
Was Viscount Althorp from 183 a year after he was born, was the 3rd Earl of Spencer after his father's death in 1834 (when he left politics).
Was promoted to Baron denman in 1834 no specifics, so we can assume he might have been called Baron or Denman in Parliament.
Was a 3rd Baronet, not much info to be found.
Was promoted to 1st Baron Monteagle of Brandon after leaving office in 1839.
From 1848-1866 he was a thrid Baronet, after that in 1866 he was promoted to 1st Baron Northbrook.
Nothing noteworthy to report.
Was a Baronet from 1846 - 1866, was granted the peerage title 1st Viscount Halifax in 1866, of Monk Bretton in York county.
granted the title 1st Earl of Beaconsfield by Queen Victoria in 1876 after his term in office as Chancellor.
Nothing noteworthy to report.
Was raised to Baronet in 1846.
granted the title 1st Earl of Beaconsfield by Queen Victoria in 1876 after his term in office as Chancellor.
Nothing noteworthy to report.
granted the title 1st Earl of Beaconsfield by Queen Victoria in 1876 after his term in office as Chancellor.
Nothing noteworthy to report.
Was granted the title 1st Viscount Sherbrooke on May 25 1880 by Queen Victoria in the London Gazette.
Nothing noteworthy to report.
1st Earl of Iddesleigh in 1885.
Nothing noteworthy to report.
Nothing noteworthy to report.

Succeeded his father in becoming 9th Baronet in 1854. "In 1906 he was raised to the peerage as Viscount St Aldwyn, of Coln St Aldwyn, in the County of Gloucester, and in 1915 he was further honoured when he was made Viscount Quenington, of Quenington, in the County of Gloucester, and Earl St Aldwyn, of Coln St Aldwyn, in the County of Gloucester" (Wikipedia source: London Gazette).
Nothing noteworthy to report.
Nothing noteworthy to report.
He retired in 1900 and was raised to the peerage as (1st) Viscount Goschen of Hawkhurst, Kent.
Nothing noteworthy to report.

Succeeded his father in becoming 9th Baronet in 1854. "In 1906 he was raised to the peerage as Viscount St Aldwyn, of Coln St Aldwyn, in the County of Gloucester, and in 1915 he was further honoured when he was made Viscount Quenington, of Quenington, in the County of Gloucester, and Earl St Aldwyn, of Coln St Aldwyn, in the County of Gloucester" (Wikipedia source: London Gazette).
In 1905, he was created a peerage, Baron Ritchie of Dundee.
Nothing noteworthy to report.
1925 accepted peerage as the Earl of Oxford and Asquith.
Was  granted a peerage but died before he could take his place in the House of Lords, 1st Earl Lloyd-George of Dwyfor and Viscount Gwynedd.
